item.title: Home Page Hero Update
item.description:
The Hero Image on the homepage will now support an optional overlay button. This button will be configurable by content editors, allowing them to set the URL, text, style (primary or secondary), and position on the image based on different breakpoints (phone, small tablet, large tablet, and desktop).
Scope of the Feature:

If there is no URL and Label included in the configuration of the component the hero image area will not be clickable and the render will not render any button UI.
It is MarComs responsibility to deliver an images in the correct size and dimensions with non critical information in the area where the button will be positioned.
Sizes: 300x350, 600x300,900x300,1200x400
Accepted images are PNG, JPG
You can only choose 1 button position, style, URL, and label for all break points.
The entire area of the Positioning grid will be clickable and cause the button to hover.
The cards part of the feature will also will have their click box expanded to their entire area.
Acceptance Criteria:

Button Configuration Options:
URL: Editors can input the target URL for the button. This URL if empty and the Label is included should default to About-ACC URL
Label: Editors can input the display text for the button.
Style:
Primary Button: Teal blue with white text.
Secondary Button: Light grey with black text.
ACC Brand Button: ACC Blue with white text
ACC Brand Reversed: White with ACC Blue Text
Position:
Options: 'Left', 'Center', and 'Right'.
Position varies depending on the breakpoint (refer to the "Button Position Based on Breakpoint" section below).
Button Position Based on Breakpoint:
Button Positioning Grid:
the Grid inset is 0 0 60px 0 to the full width and eight of the image.
1 rem padding from the edge of its inset image.
The hit area of the image should be the entire area.
Phone:
Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 4 (height)
Button should size down one step from normal.
Uploaded Size: 300w x 350h
Grid Layout: 1 column x 3 rows
Positioning:
Regardless of 'Left', 'Center', or 'Right' setting, the button will be centered in the bottom row.
Small Tablet:
Aspect Ratio: 2 (width) x 1 (height)
Uploaded Size: 600w x 300h
Grid Layout: 2 columns x 2 rows
Positioning:
Left: Bottom-left cell, centered vertically and horizontally.
Center: Bottom row, centered horizontally and vertically.
Right: Bottom-right cell, centered vertically and horizontally.
Large Tablet:
Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 1 (height)
Uploaded Size: 900w x 300h
Grid Layout: 3 columns x 2 rows
Positioning:
Left: Bottom-left cell, centered vertically and horizontally.
Center: Bottom center cell, centered horizontally and vertically.
Right: Bottom-right cell, centered vertically and horizontally.
Desktop:
Aspect Ratio: 3 (width) x 1 (height)
Uploaded Size: 1200w x 400h
Grid Layout: 3 columns x 3 rows
Positioning:
Left: Bottom-left cell of the last row, centered vertically and horizontally.
Center: Bottom center cell of the last row, centered horizontally and vertically.
Right: Bottom-right cell of the last row, centered vertically and horizontally.
Responsive Behavior:
The button's position and size should adjust dynamically based on the device's screen size and aspect ratio.
The button should not overlap important text or imagery unless specified in the design guidelines.
( this will be the responsibility of theMarCom to not place critical information in the art in the areas they selected for the button placement. )
Editor Preview:
Provide a preview in the CMS where editors can see how the button will look on different breakpoints before publishing.
QA Testing Notes:

Test button configuration for all breakpoints.
Validate button positioning aligns with the specified grid layouts.
Verify that styling changes correctly based on editor selection.
Test keyboard navigation and screen reader accessibility.
Design Reference:

See XD Link: https://xd.adobe.com/view/bd608e30-7c5e-45eb-bf89-aab42b492ae3-e833/

item.title: Boiler Plate __ EPIC: Single Page Application (SPA) Intake for [Application Name]
item.description:
back to acc

Ticket ID: #12345

This is the master ticket for the intake process of the [Application Name] as a Single Page Application (SPA). It encompasses all the necessary steps required for successful design, feasibility analysis, and initial application setup.

Proposed URL for the Project: [Fill in domain]
Requires Authentication: [Yes/No]
Data Storage: [None/Client/Server]

This checklist is roughly established by the breakdown from Outline of Tickets for SPAs in Vue

Project Initiation: Conduct a kick-off meeting involving representatives from Product Lines, UX Team, Frontend Developers, and Backend Developers to align on objectives and expectations. Define project scope and set up project tracking.
Requirement Gathering: Gather and document the design and functional requirements for the SPA. Set a milestone to finalize the requirements.
Technical Feasibility: Conduct a technical feasibility study based on the gathered design and requirements. Review and adjust project scope if necessary.
[ ] Analytics engagement: outline goals and metrics that are needed for antibiotics. Engage the analytics team and fold any technical requirements for analytics into the project from the beginning.
Design Phase: Follow-up on the design after the technical feasibility study, making necessary iterations and adjustments. Define a milestone for finalizing the design.
Development - Basic Application Setup: Define and set up the data structure and API calls, construct the page layout, create the code branch, and set up page access. Also, set up the Vue APP SHELL and initiate the application. Set a milestone for the completion of this basic application setup.
Development - Component Construction: Create multiple tickets for each component that needs to be developed or modified. Set a milestone for the completion of all components.
Development - Feature Specifics: Create multiple tickets for each application-specific feature that needs to be scaffolded. Set a milestone for the completion of all features.
Integration and Testing: Integrate components with the application and refine features in cooperation with QA. Set a milestone for the completion of integration and testing.
User Acceptance Testing: Conduct user acceptance testing to ensure that the application meets the defined requirements and user expectations. Set a milestone for the completion of UAT.
Beta Focus Group (Optional): If applicable, conduct a beta test with a focus group. Use their feedback to make final adjustments before the full launch.
Launch Preparation: Prepare for the application launch, ensuring all systems are ready and all required parties are informed.
Launch and Post-Launch Review: Launch the SPA, monitor its performance, gather feedback, and conduct a post-launch review. Set a milestone for the completion of the post-launch review.

🔶 Please fill in the details accordingly, which will greatly assist the development team in understanding and executing the required tasks.
🔶 This refined milestone-based checklist offers a comprehensive snapshot of the process needed for the transition of the application to an SPA. For each step, corresponding sub-tickets should be generated under this primary ticket. Each sub-ticket will be added to the appropriate backlog and prioritized based on its criticality and dependencies. This structure will ensure seamless management and clear tracking of progress throughout the project's lifecycle.

item.title: AI Prompt - Craft UX Ask
item.description:
I need you to act and have the knowledge of a UX SPECIALIST, your role is crucial in shaping and formatting this project request for our team's work. Your input will be invaluable in each of the following categories. Your concise writing style will guide the process. I will rely on you to prompt me for more details for each section and to fill in any necessary information. Only when you have all the details should you return the formatted intake data in markdown in a code block.   

Simple written statement in sentence Format

This can be written as a sentence or, if easier to scan, a bulleted list of short statements. The needs and values should dive deeper beyond the wants and should outline the users and problems they are trying to solve  

A few sentences should outline the user, the project, and the value.

This should be a bulleted list of short statements

This should be a bulleted list of short statements outlining the assumptions and how this might not answer the need because of the shortcomings of constraints and Limitations.
If you understand this then prompt me for the first section and after you I say Next Section should you prompt me for the next section for questions. As we go further down the intake data the more you can extrapolate from the data you already have.

item.title: KSS Documentation
item.description:
KSS, or Knyle Style Sheets, is a documentation syntax for CSS that allows developers to create a living style guide from CSS comments. It's structured to be both human-readable and machine-parsable, enabling automated tools to generate style guides from your CSS files. Here's an example of a comprehensive KSS comment block for a CSS stylesheet, including all the main options it can have:
/* A button suitable for giving a user a call to action. Style guide: Components.Buttons.Primary :hover - Highlights when hovered. :disabled - Dims the button when it cannot be interacted with. .small - A smaller button for less important actions. .large - A larger button for more important actions. Markup: <button class="btn {{modifier_class}}">Button</button> Modifiers: - .small - A small version of the primary button - .large - A large version of the primary button State classes: - .is-active - Highlights the button as active - .is-disabled - Shows the button as disabled Variables: - $btn-background-color: Color of the button background. - $btn-text-color: Color of the button text. $btn-background-color: #007bff; $btn-text-color: #ffffff; @brand Primary @dependencies - forms.css - grid.css @requires - mixins.css - variables.css @implementations - Web: components/button/button.css - iOS: components/button/button.swift - Android: components/button/button.xml */ .btn { background-color: $btn-background-color; color: $btn-text-color; /* other styles */ }
This example includes:

Description and Title: A brief description of the component or style and optionally a title.
Style Guide Reference: Indicates where in the style guide this component or style belongs.
States and Modifiers: Describes different states (:hover, :disabled) and modifiers (.small, .large) that the element can have, including their descriptions.
Markup: Provides an HTML snippet as an example of how to implement the described style.
Variables: Lists any CSS variables (custom properties) used in the style, including their default values.
Brand: Optional brand or category this component belongs to.
Dependencies: Other CSS files or assets this component depends on.
Requires: Additional resources or files that are required for this component.
Implementations: Links or references to implementations of the component in different technologies or platforms.
This structured comment allows developers and designers to understand the purpose, usage, and variations of a component at a glance. It can be processed by tools like KSS Node to generate a living style guide, ensuring documentation stays up-to-date with the code.

item.title: AI Prompt - SCRUM TICKET
item.description:
Comprehensive Prompt Template for ChatGPT Interaction and Backlog Ticket Creation
Contextual Setup for My Request:
I want you to understand and act in the specific context of being a Product Owner on a SCRUM team. Your role is to write backlog tickets for a new feature, considering all aspects typical of a Product Owner's responsibilities in a real-world scenario. I expect the tone and approach of your responses to reflect this role and context. After the prompt please ask up to 3 follow up questions if you any clarifications or supporting details. Here are some key points I want you to consider:

SCRUM Methodology Awareness: You should demonstrate a clear understanding of SCRUM principles and practices.
Role-Specific Knowledge: As a Product Owner, your focus is on maximizing the value of the product and the work of the development team.
Feature-Specific Requirements: The backlog tickets you will create should be for a specific feature, detailed in my request.
User-Centric Approach: Emphasize the importance of user stories and prioritize tasks based on user needs and project goals.
Communication Style: Your responses should mirror the communication style of a Product Owner - clear, decisive, and oriented towards actionable items.
Writing Style: Concise and clear, with a preference for listing items rather than writing out in sentences, to facilitate easy scanning.
Project Introduction:

Subject Matter: Tech stack - ASP, Vue, HTML, CSS, JavaScript, CMS Sitecore or Sitefinity
Internal Terms: [Clarification on terms like ARCHES, PaperCrane, ACC.org, CardioSmart, etc.]
ARCHES is a comprehensive front-end design system by the American College of Cardiology. It uses advanced compiler techniques to generate variations that integrate with different frameworks and brands, making it versatile for various ACC products. ARCHES primarily consists of utility classes that offer a modern approach to CSS, focusing on single-style control and separation of responsibilities between HTML and CSS. This system is flexible and adaptable, used across multiple ACC platforms, including ACC.org and CardioSmart, and supports distinct brand styles while maintaining overall coherence.
PaperCrane refers to a Component Library specifically designed for Vue.js, a progressive JavaScript framework. This library is utilized in the development of Single Page Applications (SPAs). PaperCrane contains a collection of pre-built Vue components which can be reused across different parts of the enterprise application, enhancing development speed and ensuring UI consistency.
ACC.org ACC.org is the official website of the American College of Cardiology. It serves as a comprehensive resource for cardiology professionals, offering a wide range of content including clinical updates, educational materials, guidelines, and information on cardiology conferences and events. The site is designed to support medical professionals in the field of cardiology with the latest scientific research, policy advocacy, and continuous education. It also provides tools and resources for practice support, quality improvement, and patient care in the cardiovascular field. The website caters to the needs of cardiologists, providing them with essential information to advance their knowledge and practice. This Domain is built on the CMS of Sitecore.
CardioSmart.org is a patient-centered website created by the American College of Cardiology. It provides comprehensive information about heart health and various cardiac conditions. The site is dedicated to educating patients, offering resources on heart diseases, healthy living tips, and tools to manage cardiac health. It includes topics such as heart disease prevention, treatment options, and lifestyle changes. CardioSmart.org is designed to empower patients with knowledge and tools to actively participate in their own heart care and make informed decisions about their health. This Domain is built on the CMS of SiteFinity.
ONECRM is a an effort to move our CRM from personify to Salesforce. This is a multi year effort and is complex collaboration of setting up Salesforce to fit the needs of ACC. It is also an effort of updating API, User Experience Flows, Integrations, Solutions, and Content across our digital platforms. Products that are majorly effected is the Shopping Cart that used to be Ebiz now Salesforce. Membership Application from OMA to Salesforce, and Membership Management.
Hubspot is a email services.
cvquality.acc.org serves as a hub for the ACC Quality Improvement for Institutions Program, catering primarily to healthcare professionals who focus on quality improvements and administration rather than direct clinical practice. It offers resources and initiatives like NCDR registries, accreditation services, and clinical toolkits aimed at enhancing cardiovascular care quality. The site provides valuable support and tools for healthcare facilities to implement evidence-based practices and engage in quality improvement projects, aligning with the administrative and quality improvement aspects of healthcare.
Backlog Ticket Creation:
Follow the appropriate Ticket Structure included in your knowledge base to detail your response for this ticket from the Prompt. Please ask me follow up questions to clarify or to fill out areas properly.
Backlog Ticket Structure:

Title: A concise, descriptive title for the feature or issue
Description:
User Story: Format - As a [type of user], I want [an action] so that [a value or result].
Background: Brief context or background information.
Objective: Clear statement of what the ticket aims to achieve.
Acceptance Criteria:
List of conditions that must be met for the ticket to be considered complete.
Should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART).
Dependencies: Any dependencies or prerequisites for the ticket.
Backlog Ticket Creation:
Follow the Updated Backlog Ticket Structure provided above to detail your response for this ticket In the Prompt Details below I will detail the information I have for the ticket.
Prompt Details:

Heading: [Specify the heading for the response.]
Introduction: [Brief introduction about the request or the aspect of the project being addressed.]
Main Content: [Detailed response or the created backlog ticket based on the structure provided, presented in a concise, list-based format for easy scanning.]
References or Sources: [If required, mention the need for citations or sources. This could be optional]

item.title: Front End Design at the College
item.description:
Frontend development continues to expand as a percentage of project coding to the point that some of our products, such as the clinical applications, are 100% frontend code. Over the past year, I have been putting work together to support a massive shift in how we do frontend and, in the long run, how we develop, support, and release our college software solutions. 
The most significant issue I continually see in IT is decentralized coding efforts. Decentralization leads to repetitive solutions, inconsistent behaviors, extended regression testing, bloated packages, complicated deployments, and potential code errors as we try to make security patches or upgrades.  
Focusing on improving how we execute frontend for the college and not just for a project, I have tackled four pillars.  

Unification of design but building for flexibility
Shifting to the CFD (component first development )
Creating documentation that is utilized and not just ignored
Centralizing everything for everyone
The unification of design was the first place I started. "Arches" is the current solution that enforces a Design Opps procedure to streamline requests and deliver a college-wide design system. This design system has two tenants. First, it can replicate its styles influenced by the brand and frameworks from its product space. It now covers QII, ACC, Cardiosmart, and Mobile and can be further scaled. Second is its utility framework that ensures a highly flexible practice to allow countless UI permutations without CSS mutations. Utility styling is also known as "scopeless" styling because you can build out many UI patterns without ever altering the original styles.   
https://assets.acc.org/Arches/Latest/docs/
Shifting to CFD (component first development) embraces an architecture for our frontend products and alters how we develop. CFD, as a pattern, has been around since 2012 with bootstrap. In its infancy, CFD could only capture minor token UI. Still, with the introduction of javascript models like Web Components, React, Vue CFD can now capture business logic, complicated interface interactions, and data mutations. Vue has been my primary focus as it builds on the collective knowledge of the department. Vue has the capabilities to make obsolete Jquery UI, Pager, Knockout, Angular, JqueryMobile, and many other libraries that are currently in use. IT streamlining to a single dependency allows for universal software patching for frontend security issues. 
Currently, we are creating documentation that is utilized and not just ignored. As we shift to CFD, we can use Storybook which allows for documentation around a living singular component with artificial data. This type of documentation gives a single point of Design, Development, and QA. The effort on a single element can be attached to countless projects through version control. Centralized development and QA can give us a feasible path to automated unit testing and regression testing. As new projects come online, utilizing the global-version-controlled components would benefit from standards, consistency, and quality control. Preliminary work done with Storybook around a future product under the ACC.org "Home Page Redesign." Projects could include the transcript, CSTool, GL Search, Coveo Search, and FIT Management.
Vue 2 component for reference
https://acc-style.github.io/Origami/?path=/story/welcome--to-storybook
Vue 3 component for all new work
https://assets.acc.org/papercrane/Latest/docs/
Centralizing everything for everyone. I have conversations GM, Josh G, and Micheal M, and the great work of Ling C on creating a path forward with using assets.acc.org and also moving the newly used submodule features from GIT within current and future products. Submodules empower the component work to be checked in and out from both the centralized-version-control and from projects, these efforts can be kept in sync. The vision for this project is to be controlled by ACC but utilizable by vendors.

item.title: Remediation
Mapping of Converted Components
item.description:
Arches Conversion/Excel Tables

The Mapping of Converted Components is a straightforward Excel document that records all components that have been converted. This reference document is crucial when implementing bulk conversion scripts. If the 'converted ID' column contains the term 'compatible', the scripting process should bypass this component. This protocol assumes that no modifications are necessary, as all required work has been completed within the original file. This mechanism helps ensure an efficient and error-free conversion process.

item.title: Editorial Bulk Change Notice Excel
item.description:
The process of bulk conversion is a nuanced operation that significantly depends on the scope of the pages being converted. Each bulk conversion task is unique, and while insights and learnings from previous conversions inform the process, it's important to note that a bespoke report is produced after each conversion. This report, presented in an Excel document, is a crucial tool that outlines the User Interface (UI) items within the editorial scope - including Rich Text and Custom Scripts - that require remediation following the conversion. The items are neatly categorized by sheet, each containing the Item ID, URL, and proposed remediation notes. This systematic approach provides a comprehensive view of the areas within the CMS that may need review, adjustments, or those indicating a potential function failure. Typical remediation steps include actions like "let fail," "add classes," "remove," and "replace with components," but this list is not exhaustive. If more complex actions are needed, additional notes may be added for clarity. This meticulous process ensures an efficient and methodical approach to addressing changes and potential issues post-conversion.

A listing of all pages effected by the conversion

item.title: Audit of Editorial UI
item.description:
Over time, the content areas of our CMS have seen the implementation of various User Interface (UI) solutions. Often grassroots in origin, these Editorially Created UI elements, composed of inline styles, in-page styles, and JavaScript, present considerable maintenance and update challenges.
To manage this tech debt, our bulk conversion process aims to remediate or remove these elements. The goal is to align our UI with the Arches Enterprise Design System, which entails eliminating non-conforming in-page JavaScript and Styles.
To facilitate this, we're conducting an audit of the Editorially Created UI components. This audit plays a crucial role in forming a plan that ensures website functionality while addressing unnecessary complexity.

This process involves a meticulous examination and subsequent remediation of all editorially integrated links - a prerequisite before launching any audit. Our audit also thoroughly reviews content areas embedded with script and style blocks. Particular attention is given to the returned content scrape, which is systematically converted into a Unicode format that's safe for coding.
As part of this procedure, we identify and replace certain patterns, such as "<" and ">", with their equivalent symbols, and transform specific HTML entity codes into spaces and carriage returns, thereby improving block readability. This method allows the team to evaluate readable blocks effectively and discover any "new" patterns, which aids in documenting necessary remediation steps. This systematic approach prepares us for the eventual removal of style and script blocks, creating the necessary tickets or steps as required.
Numbered Steps:

Begin by running the remediation of all editorially included links that are set to "Save" before initiating the audit.
Perform an Audit Report of content areas that contain script and style blocks on the page.
Ensure the returned content scrap is converted into a code-safe Unicode because of the Content Scrape Limitations.
Identify and replace specific patterns, such as "<" and ">", with their corresponding symbols.
Substitute certain HTML entity codes into space and transform others into carriage returns.
Evaluate the now readable blocks after the aforementioned transformations.
Discover any new patterns that emerge from the evaluation, and document the appropriate remediation steps.
Finally, create any necessary tickets or steps to prepare for the obliteration of style and script blocks.



To make the code more readable, it's crucial to replace certain Unicode characters with their typical representations. Specifically, we'll be dealing with the following conversions:

The Unicode for the carriage return, _000D_, should be replaced with a visual marker for carriage returns such as the symbol "↵".
The Unicode for the horizontal tab, _0009_, could be replaced with a few spaces for better visualization.
The Unicode for the space, _0020_, can be substituted with a visible space character.
The line feed character, represented by the Unicode _000A_, can be swapped with a new line symbol like "␤" to depict line breaks better.
The tab character, also represented by _0009_, should be replaced with a few spaces for clarity.
Finally, the Unicode for less than and greater than symbols, < and >, can be converted to their actual "<" and ">" symbols.
By transforming these Unicode characters into their corresponding visual representations, we significantly enhance the comprehensibility of the document, thus facilitating easier identification of different elements and their spacing.

Create a PRD back-up to support a rollback, if needed (requires further discussion around specific rollback tasks/steps) 
Take back-ups of both Author and Web DBs 
Need to enforce a content freeze (BL), specifically for a subset of pages/content 
Promote to PRD and run bulk conversion script in Author ONLY, do NOT publish to Delivery. 
IMPORTANT NOTE: To ensure content is NOT auto-published, there is a need to explore options. 
Option 1: Set content items to a DRAFT status when converting content in Author.  See Sitecore DRAFT workflow doc here.  Possible risk is the Original Posted Date may be updated as a result (need confirmation) 
Option 2: -- TBD 
IT to perform spot checks in Author to ensure the conversion script was completed successfully. 
BL reviews converted pages in Author and as pages are validated, publish in increments (as appropriate) 
UI, DEV, & QA teams on standby to field any questions or address any concerns 
Post Conversion/Clean Up Tasks (once all batches are complete, one-time task) 
Once conversion is complete, we will take the Arches presentations and merge them into the current legacy template presentation configurations, and delete the Arches versions, as clean up. 
QA Approach (DRAFT) 
NOTE: This approach should be visited as we progress w/ the batches.  Also, scheduled sprint content syncs should not adversely affect the Arches QA pages since they will already exist prior to the content sync. 

UI/UX team will create an Arches QA dedicated page (e.g., page name to include '_ArchesQA' suffix  in the DEV environment in support of their development & verification process. 
Once the component updates have been verified in the DEV environment, UI/UX to request a Razl content sync to SPR in coordination w/ their updates getting built and deployed to SPR. (Ricky can assist w/ Razl syncs) 
QA will then use the Arches QA dedicated page in SPR to test the target components.  Once validated in SPR, QA will work with DEV (Ricky) to sync content to upper environments (STG/RLS) as the changes are promoted. 
PRD deployment (e.g., pre-task) should include a step to sync the Arches QA dedicated page to PRD (Author ONLY, do not publish to Delivery) in order for QA validate in PRD. 
Once validated, need to ensure there is a clean-up process to remove/delete QA dedicated pages, once ready (in ALL environments) 
Notes:  
It is important that we have a way to roll back our work at any point throughout these cycles and we need to be able to do this in a way that BL can be comfortable with. This plan doesn’t really account for if something goes pear shaped in Sprint C but we should probably iron that out as well, especially if something goes wrong during the push to production. 
This looks like a three-sprint process, but we may be able to consider identifying the next batch during sprint C to speed up conversion if necessary.

item.title: KT SESSIONS
item.description:
I want to outline a comprehensive Knowledge Transfer (KT) strategy that targets the required remediation steps. The goal is to ensure a smooth transition, allowing our team to manage the work systematically and avoid overwhelming our team resources and capabilities. 
Here's a step-by-step process to guide our KT activities:
Sub-dividing the Conversion into Manageable Segments: We can accomplish tasks efficiently throughout the week by dividing the bulk conversion into themed work or manageable segments. For instance, focusing on a specific aspect like "all the pages that have tabs" will make the process more digestible and actionable.
Weekly Kick-off Meeting for Conversion Blocks: At the start of the week, we will convene a meeting where a conversion block of pages is presented. This meeting will include a live demo showing how to make the necessary changes, providing an excellent opportunity for team members to understand the process firsthand.
Standing 30-Minute Meetings throughout the Week: To ensure continuous support and clear communication, I suggest scheduling a standing 30-minute meeting every day. This stand-up meeting will be a forum to discuss any roadblocks or questions related to the assigned work. It will enable real-time problem-solving and maintain momentum in the project.
Here’s a high-level schedule to illustrate the flow:
Monday: Kick-off meeting with a conversion demo for the week's segment (e.g., pages with tabs).
Tuesday to Friday: Daily 30-minute stand-up sessions to address questions and roadblocks.
End of Week: Recap and assessment of the week's accomplishments, planning for the next segment.
By adhering to this process, we aim to create a structured approach to knowledge transfer, facilitating the handling complex conversion tasks and empowering our team with the confidence and competence needed.
Also, it's worth mentioning that our KT process is designed to be flexible and responsive to the team's evolving needs. As our collective experience and proficiency grow, we anticipate that the demand and duration of the daily stand-up meetings may not be needed or shortened. We'll continually assess the progress and adjust accordingly, ensuring our approach remains efficient and aligned with the team's capabilities. Continued feedback will be instrumental in this ongoing refinement, keeping us agile and focused on our shared goals.

ACC User Experience Team

2400 N Street NW
Washington DC, 20037

item.title: Quality of life configurations with Sitecore
item.description:
Considering the difficulties that editors encounter in distinguishing between legacy, converted, and legacy supportive components, owing to the absence of folder structure and clear naming, we've introduced a streamlined approach. All component icons are now set to grey or red by default. However, converted and supportive components, along with the majority of new work, will be marked with either blue icons for compatible renderings or green for new arches components. This blue color is intended to be the default setting both arches and legacy supportive components. It's essential for the development team to review and ensure this default setting when releasing new work into the platform. In any instance where the blue green or grey is not the icon for the rending, the setting must be promptly corrected.
Further Icon Definition allow for even easier recognition in the back end will be. Page Layout components should be Starts, Vue/JavaScript driven components should be puzzle pieces.

When looking at the display view list in the backend you only see the render name and its relative location that it is placed in the list. As the teams move forward in using more and more shared content and breaking down content into chunks the Display view gets rather unuable becuase you would see RichText written possilbly 5 times on the page the same is true with accordions. In that view is it possible to interject at least the details of the source which can be altered with a nickname like intro-text, benifit grid.....

The component dependency tree outlines the interrelationships between components in a Sitecore instance, specifically identifying those that are either children of a component or have dependent child components. Only necessary components should be configured in this instance to maintain simplicity and reduce confusion for editors. This approach also minimizes the risk of including non-supportive components by lessening the need for editors to manually add components. Ultimately, this method aids in preventing the appearance of non-supportive components within converted pages, ensuring a clean and efficient working environment.

item.title: Arches Conversion
item.description:
#acc/arches/conversion #acc/guidance
← back to acc products
Script Glossary & Categorization
--------------------------------------------------------- 
SPRINT A - Define the Batch 
--------------------------------------------------------- 

Select conversion candidate for the batch and define scope
Run an Audit Query against the code base of Sitecore within scope for code components & plan needed conversions
Run an Audit Query against the CMS Content Areas (RichText & CustomScripts) within scope for Editorial Generated UI & start planning for remediation
Groom 
--------------------------------------------------------- 
SPRINT B - Component Conversions
--------------------------------------------------------- 

Convert the components 
Deploy to lower environments DEV/SPR 
QA test the converted components 
Promote to PROD 
List of bulk changes - Mapping of changes 
--------------------------------------------------------- 
SPRINT C - Editorial Created Remediation 
--------------------------------------------------------- 

SYNC SPR 
Execute bulk conversion script with a small sample of pages in DEV/SPR - Using Mapping 
Clean up rich text via script (S&D) 
Review effected pages 
Create jira tickets for content issues identified during review 
Work with BL to resolve found issues 
Promote to RLS 
Demo with BL and obtain sign-off 
--------------------------------------------------------- 
SPRINT D - Batch Conversion
--------------------------------------------------------- 

Create PRD/Master/Web DBs backup for potential rollback 
Run bulk conversion script in Author only with auto-publishing turned off 
IT performs spot checks 
BL reviews and validates pages, with support from UI, DEV, and QA teams 
Garbage Clean up of Empty Content areas and RichText
Resync to lower environments?
Editorial training
--------------------------------------------------------- 
SPRINT Z - Done! 
--------------------------------------------------------- 

Garbage cleanup
Bulk Conversion Outline OLD
Excel Tables
Jira Tickets notes

item.title: Arches
item.description:
Front End Design at the College
Design System
Arches Conversion
Arches is the foundational design system employed by the American College of Cardiology (ACC). Leveraging advanced compiler techniques, Arches generates a multitude of variations that integrate with different frameworks and product brands. These variations are utilized across an array of products developed by the ACC.
In its basic form, Arches serves as a set of utility classes. When incorporated into a project with an existing style sheet, it can introduce new, non-destructive styling features. Additionally, Arches offers variants that seamlessly build on two popular frameworks currently in use at the College: Twitter Bootstrap

item.title: Hubspot
item.description:
How to use Subscription Types in HubSpot.
Statements of Truth

Source of record for opt ins are 1CRM
Source of record for the flag of global opt out is HubSpot.

To send any marketing email you must select a Subscription Type.
On Email Footers Manage Subscriptions = 1CRM Unsubscribe from All = HubSpot.
Email lists are made by the Marketing Communication Table.
Problems
There are not resubscribe flows because not built in 1crm.
The rub is that the subscriptions types show up on the renew page.
1CRM opt-ins do not matching the opt-ins from higher logic. Suggest going into the delta from 1crm and higher logic. Adding new opt in are a bit of work because it modifies the "pull" from 1crm to Hubspot.
Find a way if we can to suppress the one Subscription Type on the resubscribe.

item.title: Profile Tour
item.description:
We recently made some changes to how you manage your personal information. Take a quick tour of these updates to enhance your experience and make it more intuitive. 

Manage your email, phone and address details more easily and get a more comprehensive view of your ACC.org profile. 

Our new shopping cart system, makes payments a breeze. You can easily manage and save your payment methods here, making purchases faster and more seamless.  

Under "Current Membership," you can view your membership status or reprint your membership card. In "Manage Membership," you can renew your membership or alter any add-ons to your membership. 

Personalize the types of content you receive from ACC, including your regular digest email newsletter, under "Personalize ACC.org." Additionally, the new “Communication & Privacy” page, allows you to control the content you receive and share only the data you are comfortable with. Never miss an update while maintaining control over your ACC communications. 

Are you in possession of an exclusive product access code? Use the “Access Codes” page to unlock your savings on specific ACC programs or products.  

Access the “Purchas History” page for a detailed list of your past purchases of ACC programs and products.  

Saved an article on ACC.org? You can find it under the “Library” page for quick access to read again or reference later.  

Locate, view and print claimed credits and certificates on your personalized “Transcript” page.

item.title: OMA Replacement - Membership Join Us
item.description:
He has never dictated the need for the UI but he recognizes a great divide between what is shown in demo and what is currently in place in our solution.

From the quick demo I just received the dropdown is driving the options the user is eligible for which is the requirement.

The select application is a simple dropdown with only the application names that the user is eligible for. This has some lacking experiences from what is currently built which are.

A description of the differences of member types
Direct Comparison of Options
Pricing of the options before you click
A quick checklist of details you will need to fill in after you start.
This last item is what concerns JP the most because of how this impact's user experience and education before an application is kicked off.

This solution has compounding problems because of how the application selection doesn't inform the user on what information they should collect before they start and the experience of saving and returning to the application.
<<<<<<< HEAD:Family/My Family/Temp/Untitled.md

The Save and Return doesn't Resume an application but starts over with the user and in generates new records in the backend (Multiple attempted Pending applications)
The Wizard Doesn't Navigate when returning to an application you can't use the wizard as a navigation to skip around. You need to multiple select the next button and even then you can't always bypass blocking questions because the user selections don't seem to persist for the user.
These Save and Return Limitation really predicates the user to be as educated on the requirements of the application before they start because they will have to run through the application multiple times.
Absolutely, there are numerous ways to phrase this question to encourage engagement and make it easier for respondents. Here are three additional options:
Option 1 (Comparative Importance):
"Which types of content on a digital platform do you find most valuable? Please rank the following options from most valuable (1) to least valuable (5).

Top-cited articles
Videos
Podcasts
Digital Interactives
Other resources (please specify)"
Option 2 (Preference Order):
"Everyone has a preference when it comes to content on digital platforms. What's yours? Please order the following types of content based on your personal preference, with 1 being your top preference.

Top-cited articles
Videos
Podcasts
Digital Interactives
Other resources (please specify)"
Option 3 (Time Investment):
"If you had an hour to spend on a digital platform, how would you divide that time among the following types of content? This doesn't need to add up to exactly 60 minutes - we're just trying to understand what you'd prefer to spend more time with.

Top-cited articles: ___ minutes
Videos: ___ minutes
Podcasts: ___ minutes
Digital Interactives: ___ minutes
